contentrichtext.text: {{BLP sources|date=May 2011}} '''Daklon''' (born Yosef Levy) is [[Israel]]i musician.<ref name="Horowitz2010">{{cite book|last=Horowitz|first=Amy|title=Mediterranean Israeli Music and the Politics of the Aesthetic|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=oDO9S_YJMusC&pg=PA65|accessdate=10 May 2011|date=2010-04-15|publisher=Wayne State University Press|isbn=978-0-8143-3465-2|pages=63–}}</ref> ==Early life== He was born in 1944 in [[Tel Aviv]]'s [[Kerem Hateimanim]] ([[Yemenite Jew|Yemenite]]) neighborhood, as a son of Jewish-Yemeni immigrants from the Shar'ab region in Yemen. As Daklon explains the source of his nickname: "In those days everyone in the Kerem had a nickname. Your given name was only good for your ID. As a kid I was very small and thin, almost skinny (Hebrew: דק, ''dak''; ''daq''). Therefore they called me ''Daklon''." He started his musical career as an 11-year-old when his teacher sent him to do a spot for a religious music radio show. ==Music== Daklon was first inspired to take his music more seriously by [[Morocco]]-born singer Joe Amar at the end of the 1950s. Daklon took [[Greece|Greek]] and [[India]]n songs and put Hebrew words to them in the 1960s when his career was launched. He is famed for his performances with Yemenite virtuosos [[Haim Moshe]] and [[Avihu Medina]]. Daklon songs are usually themed on his love for the [[land of Israel]] and the [[Tetragrammaton|God of Israel]].
